No, I have Haynes notes in Lundgren's copy of the Kakudaifu.  They 
are mos=
tly reserved to attributions by Torigoye as to first, second, 
some referen=
ces to which collection the piece came from, and a few 
fake, etc.  I belie=
ve he transcribed them from his own copy for 
Lundgren and were notes he to=
ok from Torigoye.  That book will be 
available after I'm gone which is usu=
ally being arranged by several 
folks at any given time so you probably won=
't have to wait long(LOL)!

PS:  No.

> This is the original, first edition Japanes=
e printing of 
the 'Nakamura Kakudaifu Nobuie Tsuba Shu' by Akiyama, Kyusak=
u, 1926, 
Tokyo, or, 'Collection of Rubbings of the Nobuie Sword Guards 
be=
longing to Nakamura'.  This is printed in the Japanese acordion 
folded sew=
n binding style and is practically flawless with age 
related soiling to th=
e cover (see pic) with both cover fasteners 
intact.  The interior book is =
'Fine'.  I have only seen two copies 
available in the last four years and =
this is one.  The text is of 
course in Japanese but the rubbings are the p=
rimary source for study 
of the Shodai and Nidai Nobuie tsuba, not the late=
r reproductions.  I 
will be happy to include a transcription of the Haynes=
 notes from his 
study with Dr. Torigoye as to the generation/etc. for each=
 page where 
noted in the Lundgren copy.  144 pgs. A most rare book. 
>   -=
